--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Ni=
kolai, you have the main idea right but the one aspect of your 
> descripti=
on that I would correct is the idea that the substrate must
> be a perceptr=
on.

thanks Ken, as I understood, you call 'substrate' a final ANN that eva=
luates the solution to the problem activating each node one by one where ea=
ch node uses the same activation function.
In a paper about CPPNs you say t=
hat CPPN is not an ANN and this is why it is called 'CPPN', i agree. But wh=
en a CPPN produces weights for an ANN, the result (substrate) must be an AN=
N. If each node of the substrate is not perceptron type (i.e does not have =
a sigmoid activation function), then we can not call it an ANN, right ? It =
could be called as some sort of an "expression tree"? And if it does not ha=
ve many hidden layers, it would represent a simple (repetitive, symmetrical=
, etc) expression. A 'simple expression at large scale' if it is dealing wi=
th large number of connections. 
Please correct me if i am missing somethin=
g.
Thanks
Nikolai
